Advice Text: Subtract your age from 120. That percentage of your portfolio can be in the stock market.
Always take the employer's 401k match. It's an immediate 100% return on investment.
Adding googly eyes to objects is a funny and harmless prank.
If you wouldn't take advice from them, don't worry about their opinion.
What you allow is what will continue.
Learn to confidently sit alone at a bar–it's a skill that will serve you.
If you're the one always apologizing, you may not the problem.
Never send an angry email on the same day you wrote it.
An apron is simply a cape worn backwards.
Never wake someone up to ask if they're asleep.
Don't be afraid to ask for help when you need it.
Don't ask for a sip if they are drinking from a straw.
Be really sure before congratulating a pregnancy.
Nothing gets less awkward by avoiding it.
Keep a backup of important files–technology fails when you least expect it.
People are showing you who they are all the time–believe what you are seeing.
When someone's having a bad day, assume they need kindness rather than judgment.
Don't let a bad moment convince you it's a bad day.
Being bad at something is the uncomfortable first step of getting good at it.
The best ideas often come after you think you've run out.
If you want better answers, ask better questions.
The best way to get better at writing is to read more.
Review and reset your annual goals every year on your birthday.
Converting photos to black and white is a simple way to make them look more professional and refined.
A book left face-down and open is an insult to both the spine and the story.
Always have a book you're reading–it keeps your mind engaged.
Boost your creativity by reducing the time between inspiration and action.
When you borrow something, return it in better condition than you received it.
If you borrow a pen, return it. If you forget, replace it.
The quickest way to break a spiral is physically–move, breathe, reset.
Nobody ever regretted bringing snacks to a long event
Budgeting tells your money where to go instead of wondering where it went.
Buy quality where it matters.
If you need an immediate response, call. If it can wait, send a text.
If a camera’s out, keep your drink discreet—you’ll thank yourself later.
Focus on the things you can control.
Put the cap back on the toothpaste.
Get your car detailed on its birthday.
A car is not an investment, it loses value immediately.
If you say “we should catch up sometime,” mean it–or don't say it.
Celebrate other people's wins like they're your own.
Know how to change a tire, even if you never have to do it.
Adapt to changing circumstances, but stay true to your guiding principles.
Don't ignore the check engine light.
Revisit a childhood food just for the nostalgia.
Christmas card inserts work best when they're easy to scan and feature mostly pictures.
Send Christmas cards each year, including a short hand-written note to express that you appreciate them.
Learn how to ask for what you want– clearly and kindly.
Know how to make one great cocktail for your guests.
Be comfortable with silence–it's a sign of true friendship and self-assurance.
Never argue with a stranger in the comments section.
Don't waste energy arguing with people committed to misunderstanding you.
Do what you committed to doing–reliability is rarer than talent.
The only person to compare yourself to is the person you used to be.
Before complaining, consider offering a solution.
If you think something kind about someone, say it. Compliments should never be hoarded.
The best way to get a good seat at a concert? Make friends with the people in front of you.
Confidence is not knowing everything–it's knowing you can handle anything.
When you avoid conflict to keep the peace, you start a war within yourself.
Learn to recognize constellations in the night sky.
Cooking twice a week saves more money than you think.
Never correct someone's pronunciation if you know what they mean.
Be curious. Ask “why?”
Having trouble making a choice? Go for a walk. Don't come back until you've decided.
Never underestimate the power of taking a deep breath before you react.
Be cognizant of your digital footprint, tread lightly.
When giving directions, use landmarks, not just street names.
Learn to cook at least one dish from each continent.* (* except Antarctica)
When you're a dinner guest in someone's home, offer to help with the dishes.
If you don't have time to do it right, you don't have time to do it twice.
Donate something you don't use every time you buy something new.
Learn to say "I don't know" when you don't. It's a sign of honesty, not weakness.
When in doubt, overdress– not to impress others, but to honor the occasion.
If you show up early, offer to help.
It is so much easier to just be early than to try to be on time.
Most problems are easier to prevent than to fix.
The older you get, the more effort it takes to maintain friendshipsÑbe the one who reaches out.
When an elderly person tells a story, listen–even if it's one you've heard before.
Embrace failure as essential steps on the path to learning and growing.
An emergency fund can change a major crisis into a minor inconvenience.
Creativity should always be encouraged. Judgement comes later.
Feeling entitled is a quick way to finding
Add an hour to your ETA–two if traveling with kids or pets.
Invest in experiences, not just things. Memories outlast most possessions.
Be a hero. Keep an extra charger in your bag.
The best outcome is to succeed. The next best is to fail quickly.
When you see someone taking a family photo, offer to take it so they can be in the picture.
When a family member gets sick, your world gets a whole lot smaller.
If someone is doing you a favor, don't micromanage how they do it.
Stop waiting to ‘feel like it.’ Action creates motivation.
Understand how to read a balance sheet, and income and cash flow statements.
Your first reaction to something stressful is often your worst one.
Know how to properly fold a fitted sheet.
Keep a flashlight next to your bed–power outages don't wait for you to find your phone.
Your future self will not be mad at you for flossing.
Don't let the food delivery app decide your tip.
Forgive generously.
If an app is free, you're not the customer–you're the product.
A fresh coat of paint can fix almost anything.
When a recipe calls for fresh garlic, don't substitute garlic powder.
If a friend plays a song for you, listen like it matters. Because it does.
Don't treat your empathetic friends like they're your therapist.
If you borrow a car, return it with a full tank of gas.
Write thank-you notes before they feel overdue.
Learn how to negotiate, practice at garage sales.
The garbage tells you when it needs to be taken out
Don't ghost people in professional settings.
The best gift you can give someone is your full attention.
Don't go out without a plan of how you will get home.
Learn what it takes to maintain a good credit score.
Practice gratitude, daily.
Nothing good happens in a group chat after midnight.
Just because you'd feel guilty saying ‘no' doesn't mean you should say ‘yes'.
A firm handshake, good posture, and eye contact deliver a strong first impression.
A handwritten note can mean much more than a text or email.
While you're decluttering, turn all the hangers around, after 3 months, donate anything still facing the other way.
You don't need a cape to be a hero, just the courage to do what's right when nobody's watching.
Hold the door an extra second for the person behind you–small gestures stick.
When handing scissors to someone, hold them by the sharp end.
Send a quick “home safe” text. It takes seconds, it means everything.
Be honest with yourself about your actual capacity.
Always keep an extra house key somewhere safe.
Hug kids after discipline–so they remember the love.
If you ignore your mail long enough, it becomes a to-do list... with interest.
Just because you imagine what others think of you doesn't make those thoughts trueÑor important.
The fastest way to improve your day is to make someone else's day better.
Be mindful of how you speak to yourself–your inner voice matters.
Learn how to introduce yourself in an interesting way.
Invest in good luggage. Cheap suitcases will betray you.
The hardest part of investing... is doing nothing.
Don't wait for an invite to learn. Be curious.
When in doubt, bring a jacket.
Always take the time to write a thoughtful thank you note after an interview.
If a job feels sketchy in the interview, it won't get better.
Don't offer “Let me know if you need anything.”
If you keep waiting for the ‘perfect time,' you'll wait forever. Just start.
Always have a go-to karaoke song.
Keep in touch with your friends, they want to hear from you.
Nobody cares how much you know until they know how much you care.
Never eat the last cookie.
Let others know before you take the last piece.
A late reply is better than no reply.
Don't make fun of someone's laugh. That's their happiness.
If someone shows you a meme, laugh, even if you've seen it before.
Laundry will never truly be ‘done.'
Seek out a good lawyer, mechanic, and tailor.
Lay out what you'll need the night before.
Learn one magic trick or bar trick.
When traveling abroad, learn a few basic phrases in the local language.
Leave places better than you found them.
Leave it in your online cart overnight before purchasing.
Buy lemonade from kids–invest in their ambition.
Let someone merge in traffic–kindness costs nothing.
You can not sustain lifestyle creep exceeding your income.
Turn off the lights when you leave the room.
If someone is draining you, limit access, not just interaction.
Listen more than you talk, but don't let others silence you.
Never loan money you can't afford to lose.
Support your local high school and community theatre.
Never tell someone they look tired.
Make your bed every morning.
When someone shares good news, match their enthusiasm.
You can make a meal out of whatever is in the fridge.
Set measurable goals.
Don't let your happiness depend on what others have.
Keep medicine well-stocked–your future sick self will thank you.
If you get to meet one of your heroes, keep it short and meaningful.
If you can't decide between two menu items, pick the one you've never tried before.
The quickest way to annoy your coworkers is to microwave fish.
There's no acceptable excuse for missing your child's birthday.
A problem you can throw money at isn't really a problem–it's an expense.
When bringing drinks to a party, always bring more ice than you think you'll need.
Take a lot more walks.
The person who asks the most questions in the conversation walks away the most liked.
Go to a museum alone and take your time.
Use clear nail polish to reduce a windshield crack from spreading.
Avoid negative energy. It spreads like a virus.
It's okay to change your mind when you get new information.
Remember,every news story comes with a perspective, and usually a profit motive.
You need not a special occasion to use the nice dishes.
When you feel you need to race to catch up, try to remember this is not actually a race.
Not making a decision is a decision–usually a bad one.
Never let anyone tell you they are not creative. Never tell yourself you are not creative.
Not every storm is yours to weather.
Most people are too distracted to judge you–do your thing.
If someone needs to be convinced to like you, they're not your people.
Keep a notebook or notes app for capturing ideas, thoughts and quotes.
Keep proficient on at least one musical instrument.
Memorize one poem, quote, and speech that move you.

Don't try to one-up a friend's story. Let them enjoy their moment
in the spotlight.
Order of operations runs left to right: 8/2(2+2) is 16 not 1.
If you can't find things in under a minute, you don't have a working organization system.
Over-explaining invites negotiation.
When feeling overwhelmed, ask: What is the next actionable step?
When you make a mistake, own it and apologize sincerely.
Own a plunger before you need one.
If you break something in a store, own up to it.
Pack a swimsuit. Even if you don't think you'll need it.
When packing, bring half the clothes and twice the money.
Pamplemousse is the definitive flavor of LaCroix.
Do not convince yourself that you cannot parallel park.
Your path is your own. It's hard because it's yours and hasn't been blazed by others.
Pay yourself first.
You don't have to be perfect to be loved.
Don't judge yourself by comparing to others–focus on beating your own personal best.
Assemble yourself a personal board of advisors–trusted folks you can lean on for life's big calls.
When a pet wants attention, give it. You'll miss those moments later.
If a pet trusts someone, that tells you something. If they don't, that tells you something too.
No phones at the dinner table.
Assume traffic is the norm, not the exception.
A curated playlist is an intimate invitation into someone's world.
People are remarkably bad at predicting their own behavior.
Your most valuable work each day is choosing the right problem to focus on.
Don't let the gas gauge drop below a quarter tank.
It's a book club. Read the book.
Before signing anything, read it through twice.
Snap a photo of receipts for big purchases.
If you intend to leave a voicemail, rehearse it aloud to avoid sounding awkward.
Be known for remembering people’s birthdays.
When renting cars, splurge on models you'd love to try but never plan to own.
Offer to pay back once, if they decline, don’t insist. Sincerely say ‘thank you’.
If the Wi-Fi isn't working, try restarting the router before complaining.
Return anything you borrow–and do so promptly.
Nobody's happy when you run late.
Learn basic plumbing fixes. Know how to stop a running toilet.
Just because something is on sale doesn’t mean you need it.
Build sand castles on the beach.

Sarcasm seldom lands the
way you
think it
will.
By saving today you are giving yourself options tomorrow.
Be the first to say hello–it sets the tone.
It is okay to say “no”, politely but firmly. Boundaries are important.
Say their name back to them–it helps you remember and makes them feel seen.
Wear a scent that makes you feel put together.
Be kind to yourself, self-compassion is a strength not a weakness.
Learn to sew a button and fix a hem.
Return your shopping cart—it’s a silent test of character.
Learn a signature appetizer or dessert to bring to potlucks.
Write down your dreams, even the silly ones. They might not be so silly later.
Celebrate the small wins.
A smile can brighten someone's day.
Smoking doesn’t make a statement anymore—it just shortens the story.
Check your spelling before hitting send.
When your group is struggling to split the bill, just round up and move on.
Spontaneity is so much fun until the credit card bills come in.
Stand when someone's parents enter the room.
Go stargazing in a place with no city lights.
Stay multi-lingual.
When cooking, always stick to the recipe the first time.
If you enjoy a street performer's work, tip them.
No one regrets stretching more.
When staying at someone's house as a guest, strip the bed before you leave.
Watch the sunrise once a year just to remind yourself how big the world is.
Sunscreen is cheaper than regret.
Surround yourself with people who will fight for you in rooms that you're not in.
Take the stairs when you can–small choices add up.
When in doubt, take the photo.
The person talking the loudest is usually the least prepared.
Teach a class on a subject you know well.
Tell the people who matter to you that they matter.
Text your parents back
Say thank you to bus drivers, janitors, and those in service.
Write thank-you notes before they feel overdue.
When you take the last piece, throw the box away.
Value your time more than money, and experiences over stuff.
Time with others is finite and precious.
Tin foil cannot go in the microwave.
Tip generously.
When a toddler hands you a toy phone, you answer it.
Start tracking what actually makes you happy.
If you wouldn't take advice from someone, don't take criticism from them either.
Travel. Early and often.
Traveling abroad builds empathy for other cultures.
The way people treat animals tells you a lot about them.
If something feels off–even if can’t explain why–still trust that feeling.
Turn off high beams for oncoming cars.
Two dogs are better than one, both for you and especially for each other.
If it takes less than two minutes, do it now.
If choosing between two options feels impossible, they're probably both fine.
Unfollow accounts that make you feel bad about yourself.
Use your wit to light up a room, not to own it.
Avoid video games that depict real guns or real violence.
White vinegar and baking soda can clean almost anything.
Visit the landmarks in your own city just like a tourist would.

Have a say in the world you are inheriting.
Vote.
Walk into every room like you belong there–because you do.
When walking with someone, match their pace.
Wash your hands every time you are in a bathroom.
Keep a reusable water bottle with youÑhydration is key.
Always wear your seatbelt.
If someone is wearing headphones, assume they don't want to talk.
Start the week off with a tidy home.
Find a better conversation starter than “So, what do you do?”
Finding something to improve is rarely the problem. The real challenge is knowing when to stop.
If you have to whisper it, you probably shouldn't.
Word puzzles will keep your mind sharp.
Worrying is just paying interest on a problem you don't even have yet.
You will never be worth more than you think you are worth.
